question: What happens in hypertrophy -
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., increase in size of cells. Atrophy. Hypertrophy. Hyperplasiao Reduced size of an organ or tissue resulting from a decrease in cell size and number. o Caused by ischemia, ageing, malnutrition etc. o May result due to chronic absence of stimulus (disuse atrophy)-o Increase in size and function of cells. o Results due to increase in growth factors or tropic stimuli. o Includes puberty; lactafing breasts and skeletal muscle fibres (in body builders). o Increase in number of cells in tissues/organ. o Results due to increase in growth factors, increased expression of growth promoting genes and increased DNA synthesis. o It persists so long as the stimulus is present. o e. g. breast development at puberty, endometrial hyperplasia, benign hyperplasia of prostate, hyperplasia of liver cells after partial hepatectoinv.
topic_name: Cellular Responses and Adaptations to Stress

question: Eosinophilia in necrosed tissue is due to -
exp: Ans. is 'c' i. e., Denaturation of protein o Necrotic cells show increased eosinophilia in hematoxylin and eosin (H & E) stains. o It is due to -i.) Loss of cytoplasmic RNA (or ribonucleoprotein/RNP) which binds the blue dye, hematoxylin. ii) Denatured cytoplasmic proteins which bind the red dye, eosin.
topic_name: Cellular Responses and Adaptations to Stress

question: A patient who was previously with good muscle mass, now presents with decreased muscle mass. There is history of RTA which led him to be bedridden for 6 months. This decrease in muscle mass is best explained by:
exp: Ans. (d) Atrophy. Ref: Robbings pathology 9th ed. /36* Prolonged disuse of muscle can cause atrophy of muscle leading to decreased muscle mass in this patient (atrophy of disuse). Other Causes of Atrophy can be* Loss of innervation (denervation atrophy)* Diminished blood supply (ischemic/senile atrophy)* Inadequate nutrition* Loss of endocrine stimulation* Pressure
topic_name: Cellular Responses and Adaptations to Stress

question: Inceased accumulation of fluid in the interstitial space is described as -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Edema o Edema: accumulation of fluid in the interstitial spaceo Effusion: accumulation of fluid in the body cavities
topic_name: Cellular Responses and Adaptations to Stress

question: In individuals who donate one lobe of the liver for transplantation, the remaining organ soon grows back to its original size. This is an example of which adaptive mechanism:
exp: Ans. (c) Hyperplasia. Ref: Robbin's pathology 9th ed. 136* In individuals who donate one lobe of the liver for transplantation, the remaining cells proliferate so that the organ soon grows back to its original size. This is a classic example of compensatory hyperplasia.
topic_name: Cellular Responses and Adaptations to Stress

question: Reversible change from on cell type to other is known as?
exp: Ans. is 'c' i. e., Metaplesia o Metaplasia is an adaptive change in which one adult (mature) cell type is replaced by another adult (mature) cell. It is completely reversibleo Hypertrophy refers to an increase in the size of cells without increase in the number, resulting in an increase in the size of tissue. o Hyperplasia refers to an increase in number of cells without increase in cell sizeo Dysplasia is disordered growth with lack of uniformity of individual cells.
topic_name: Cellular Responses and Adaptations to Stress
